Prerequisites: MAT 1033 OR MTB 1103 OR APPROPRIATE PLACEMENT SCORE
Course Description: THIS IS A SURVEY COURSE OF FINANCIAL ACCOUNTING WITH THE MAJOR EMPHASIS ON THE STUDY OF COST ACCOUNTING FOR MANUFACTURING AND NON-MANUFACTURING ENTITIES.  STUDENTS WILL STUDY DEBITS, CREDITS, JOURNAL ENTRIES, AND PREPARATION OF FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.  STUDY OF COST ACCOUNTING WILL CONCENTRATE ON COST TERMINOLOGY AND CONCEPTS.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
POLK COMMUNITY COLLEGE IS QUALITY-DRIVEN EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION PROVIDING DEGREE, CAREER, AND LIFELONG LEARNING PROGRAMS WITHIN AN ENVIRONMENT OF EXCELLENCE AND COMMITMENT TO STUDENT SUCCESS.  AS SUCH, PCCS A.S. DEGREE PROGRAM OUTCOMES ADDRESS COMPETENCE IN CAREER AREAS.  A PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS COURSE IS COMPETENCE RELATED TO THE FOLLOWING PROGRAM OUTCOME(S):  APPLY ACCOUNTING CONCEPTS IN ORDER TO CONDUCT PRICE-COST ANALYSES AND MAKE APPROPRIATE PURCHASING AND INVENTORY CONTROL DECISIONS.

COURSE OBJECTIVES:
UPON SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS COURSE, STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
DEFINE BASIC TERMS AND CONCEPTS USED IN ACCOUNTING THEORY. 
DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF VARIOUS BUSINESS TRANSACTIONS AND HOW THESE TRANSACTIONS ARE ACCOUNTED FOR BY BUSINESS ENTITIES
UNDERSTAND THE FORMULATION OF FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND HOW THEY ARE UTILIZED BY BUSINESS ENTITIES
UNDERSTAND THE NATURE OF COSTS 
UNDERSTAND THE USES OF COST ALLOCATION 
DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO USE COST INFORMATION TO MAKE A VARIETY OF MANAGEMENT DECISIONS
